<BR>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Exhibit 10.1  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>International
Business Machines Corporation ("IBM") </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=4><B>Stock Option Award Agreement  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="77%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Plan</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2>IBM 1999 Long-Term Performance Plan (the "Plan")</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Identification</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Name: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Sample</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Home Country &amp; Employee ID: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Sample</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Award Information</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Date of Grant: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>[Month, Day, Year]</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Number of Options Granted: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>XX</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Grant Price: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>$XX</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Option Vesting Date: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>[Month, Day, Year three years after the Date of Grant]</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Vesting and Term</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
The Options are unvested until the third anniversary of the Date of Grant (the "Option Vesting Date"), on which date they will become 100% vested and exercisable.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Subject to earlier termination pursuant to the sections entitled "Termination of Employment" and "Cancellation and Rescission" below, the Options shall expire on the close of business on the tenth anniversary of the Date of Grant (the "Stated
Expiration Date").</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Death or Disability</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
In the event of your death, all Options shall become fully exercisable and remain exercisable for their full term.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
In the event you become disabled (as described in Section 12 of the Plan) while employed by the Company, any unvested Options shall continue to vest and be exercisable as if you were fully employed.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Termination of Employment</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
In the event that your employment with the Company terminates prior to the Option Vesting Date:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="71%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
any options that are not exercisable as of the date your employment terminates shall be canceled immediately; provided, however, if you are an executive when your employment terminates (other than for cause) after you have attained age 55, completed
at least 15 years of service with the Company at the time of termination, and completed at least one year of active service during the period between the Date of Grant and the Option Vesting Date (the "Vesting Period"), the Options granted hereunder
will be prorated for the number of months completed as an active employee during the Vesting Period, and the resulting prorated number of options shall vest and be exercisable for the full term as set forth above.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="71%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
any options that are exercisable as of the date your employment terminates (other than for cause) will remain exercisable for 90 days after the date of termination, after which any unexercised options are canceled; provided, however, if you are an
executive when your employment terminates (other than for cause) after you have attained age 55 and completed at least 15 years of service with the Company at the time of termination, any options that are exercisable as of the date your employment
terminates shall remain exercisable for the full term as set forth above.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="71%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- insert table folio -->
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=1,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="3",CHK=682063,FOLIO='blank',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]MA2534A.;4',USER='MKEANE',CD='23-FEB-2005;13:49' -->
<!-- end of table folio -->
<TABLE WIDTH="77%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="71%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
If your employment terminates for cause, all options are canceled immediately.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Cancellation and Rescission</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
You understand that IBM may cancel, modify, rescind, suspend, withhold or otherwise limit or restrict this award in accordance with the terms of the Plan, including, without limitation, canceling or rescinding this award if you render services for a
competitor prior to, or during the Rescission Period. You understand that the Rescission Period that has been established is 12 months.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
All determinations regarding enforcement, waiver or modification of the cancellation and rescission and other provisions of the Plan and this Agreement (including the provisions relating to death, disability and termination of employment) shall be
made in IBM's sole discretion.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
You agree that the cancellation and rescission provisions of the Plan and this Agreement are reasonable and agree not to challenge the reasonableness of such provisions, even where forfeiture of options is the penalty for violation.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Non-Solicitation</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
In consideration of this award, you agree that during your employment with the Company and for one year following the termination of your employment for any reason, you will not directly or indirectly: a) hire, solicit or make an offer to any
employee of the Company (as defined in the Plan) to be employed or perform services outside of the Company; or b) solicit, for competitive business purposes, any customer of the Company with which you were involved as part of your job
responsibilities during the last year of your employment with the Company. By accepting this award, you acknowledge that IBM would suffer irreparable harm if you fail to comply with the foregoing, and that IBM would be entitled to any appropriate
relief, including money damages, equitable relief and attorneys' fees.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Jurisdiction, Governing Law, Expenses and Taxes</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
You submit to the exclusive jurisdiction and venue of the federal or state courts of New York, County of Westchester, to resolve all issues that may arise out of or relate to this Agreement.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of New York, without regard to conflicts or choice of law rules or principles.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
If you or IBM bring an action to enforce this Agreement and IBM prevails, you will pay all costs and expenses incurred by IBM in connection with that action and in connection with collection, including reasonable attorneys' fees.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
If IBM, in its sole discretion, determines that it has incurred or will incur any obligation to withhold taxes as a result of this award, IBM may withhold the number of shares that it determines is required to satisfy such liability and, to the
extent that such amounts are not withheld, you will pay to IBM any amount demanded by IBM for the purpose of satisfying such liability.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
Other Terms and Conditions</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
In consideration of this Option Grant, you agree to (i) comply with the terms of the Plan and this Agreement, including those provisions relating to cancellation and rescission of awards and (ii) that by your acceptance of this award, all awards and
options previously granted to you under the Plan or prior IBM plans are subject to the terms set forth above under "Cancellation and Rescission" and "Jurisdiction, Governing Law, Expenses and Taxes." The Company may alter, amend or terminate this
Agreement without your consent, upon written notice to you.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="21%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="71%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

and you consent to receiving information and materials in connection with this Award or any subsequent awards under the Company's long term performance plans, including without limitation any prospectuses and plan documents, by any means of

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Income
from continuing operations before income taxes excludes (a)&nbsp;amortization of capitalized interest and (b)&nbsp;the company's share in the income and losses of
less-than-fifty percent owned affiliates.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Included
in the ratio calculation are preferred stock dividends of $10&nbsp;million for 2001 and $20&nbsp;million for 2000, respectively, or $14&nbsp;million for 2001 and
$29&nbsp;million in 2000 representing the pre-tax income that would be required to cover such dividend requirements based on the company's effective tax rate for 2001 and 2000,
respectively. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="cc2534_report_of_management_internati__rep03673"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_cc2534_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF MANAGEMENT<BR>  <BR>    International Business Machines Corporation and Subsidiary Companies    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>MANAGEMENT RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL INFORMATION  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Responsibility for the integrity and objectivity of the financial information presented in this Annual Report rests with IBM management. The accompanying
financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, applying certain estimates and judgments as required. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM
maintains an effective internal control structure. It consists, in part, of organizational arrangements with clearly defined lines of responsibility and delegation of authority, and
comprehensive systems and control procedures. An important element of the control environment is an ongoing internal audit program. Our system contains self-monitoring mechanisms, and actions are
taken to correct deficiencies as they are identified. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To
assure the effective administration of internal controls, we carefully select and train our employees, develop and disseminate written policies and procedures, provide appropriate
communication channels, and foster an environment conducive to the effective functioning of controls. We believe that it is essential for the company to conduct its business affairs in accordance with
the highest ethical standards, as set forth in the IBM Business Conduct Guidelines. These guidelines, translated into numerous languages, are distributed to employees throughout the world, and
reemphasized through internal programs to assure that they are understood and followed. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PricewaterhouseCoopers
LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, is retained to audit IBM's consolidated financial statements and management's assessment of the
effectiveness of the company's internal control over financial reporting. Its accompanying report is based on audits
conducted in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Audit Committee of the Board of Directors is composed solely of independent, non-management directors, and is responsible for recommending to the Board the independent
registered public accounting firm to be retained for the coming year, subject to stockholder ratification. The Audit Committee meets periodically and privately with the independent registered public
accounting firm, with the company's internal auditors, as well as with IBM management, to review accounting, auditing, internal control structure and financial reporting matters. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>MANAGEMENT'S REPORT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting of the company. Internal control over financial
reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail,
accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation
of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance
with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition
of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework issued by
the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. Based on this evaluation, management concluded that the company's internal control over financial reporting was effective as of
December&nbsp;31, 2004. Management's assessment of the effectiveness of the company's internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 has been audited by
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report which is included herein. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ce2534_report_of_independent_register__rep05097"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ce2534_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM<BR>  <BR>    International Business Machines Corporation and Subsidiary Companies    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>To the Stockholders and Board of Directors of International Business Machines Corporation:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have completed an integrated audit of International Business Machines Corporation's 2004 consolidated financial statements and of its internal control over
financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 and audits of its 2003 and 2002 consolidated financial statements in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board
(United States). Our opinions, based on our audits and the reports of other auditors, are presented below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our opinion, based on our audits and the report of other auditors, the accompanying consolidated financial statements appearing on pages 40 through 91 present
fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiary companies at December&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, and the results of their
operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
These financial statements are the responsibility of the company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits. We did not audit the
financial statements of the company's Business Consulting Services Reporting Unit (which includes the consulting practice acquired from us as discussed in note&nbsp;C) for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2004, December&nbsp;31, 2003 and the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, which statements reflect total revenues of 14.3&nbsp;percent, 14.5&nbsp;percent and
4.3&nbsp;percent of the related consolidated totals in the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively. Those statements were audited by other auditors whose report thereon has
been furnished to us, and our opinion expressed herein, insofar as it relates to the amounts included for the company's Business Consulting Services Reporting Unit, is based solely on the report of
the other auditors. We conducted our audits of these statements in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit of
financial statements includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant
estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits and the report of other auditors provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also, in our opinion, based on our audit and the report of other auditors, management's assessment, included in Management's Report on Internal Control over
Financial Reporting appearing on page 9, that the company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 based on criteria established in Internal
Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO), is fairly stated, in all material respects, based on those criteria. Furthermore, in
our opinion, based on our audit and the report of other auditors, the company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2004,
based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the COSO. The company's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting
and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting. Our responsibility is to express opinions on management's assessment and on the effectiveness of the company's
internal control over financial reporting based on our audit. We did not examine the effectiveness of the controls over the initiation and recording of revenue transactions and the recording of direct
costs at the company's Business Consulting Services Reporting Unit as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. The effectiveness of those controls was examined by other auditors whose report has been furnished to
us, and our opinions expressed herein, insofar as they relate to the effectiveness of those controls, are based solely on the report of the other auditors. We conducted our audit of internal control
over financial reporting in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. An audit of internal control over financial reporting includes obtaining
an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, evaluating management's assessment, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing
such other procedures as we consider necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit and the report of the other auditors provide a reasonable basis for our opinions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures
that (i)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii)&nbsp;provide
reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and
expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or
timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>
<IMG SRC="g903129.jpg" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="363" HEIGHT="40">
  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
NEW YORK, NEW YORK <BR>
FEBRUARY 22, 2005 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>10</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=3,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=710647,FOLIO='10',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CE2534A.;12',USER='NLUCCA',CD='24-FEB-2005;11:46' -->

NAME="page_cg2534_1_11"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="cg2534_management_discussion_internat__man03724"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_cg2534_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION<BR>  <BR>    International Business Machines Corporation and Subsidiary Companies    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=3><B>Road Map  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The financial section of the International Business Machines Corporation (IBM and/or the company) 2004 Annual Report, consisting of this
Management Discussion, the Consolidated Financial Statements that follow and the notes related thereto, comprises 83 pages of information. This Road Map is designed to provide you with some
perspective regarding the information contained in the financial section and a few helpful hints for reading the document. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>IBM'S BUSINESS MODEL  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company's business model is built to support two principal goals: helping clients succeed in delivering business value by becoming more efficient and
competitive through the use of business insight and information technology (IT) solutions; and providing long-term value to shareholders. In support of these objectives, the business model
has been developed over time through strategic investments in services and technologies that have the best long-term growth and profitability prospects based on the value they deliver to
clients. In addition, the company is committed to its employees and the communities in which it operates. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
model is designed to allow for flexibility and periodic rebalancing. In 2004, 14 acquisitions were completed, all in software and services, at an aggregate cost of over
$2&nbsp;billion, and in the fourth quarter the company announced the agreement to sell its Personal Computing Division, a unit of the Personal Systems Group. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's portfolio of capabilities ranges from services that include business performance transformation services to software, hardware, fundamental research, financing and the
component technologies used to build larger systems. These capabilities are combined to provide business insight and solutions in the enterprise computing space. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
terms of financial performance, over the last two years, the company has increased its participation in the high-growth areas of its industry, while at the same time
maintaining a breadth of capabilities that has allowed it to gain share in key markets during changing economic environments. In general, this strategy results in less volatile returns overall,
because each individual capability has unique financial attributes. Some involve contractual long-term cash and income streams while others involve cyclical transaction-based sales. The
annuity-like business delivers incremental growth with a high degree of stability and provides substantial cash. New engagements deliver more significant revenue growth and require a level
of investment to generate success. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
terms of marketplace performance&#151;i.e., the ability to deliver client value&#151;it is important to understand that the fundamental strength of this business model
is not found in the breadth of the portfolio alone, but in the way the company creates business solutions from among its capabilities and relationships. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>TRANSPARENCY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Transparency is a primary goal of successful financial reporting. The following are the key elements you will find in this year's Annual Report. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2004, the company, in accordance with Section&nbsp;404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, conducted an evaluation of its internal control over financial reporting and
concluded that the internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2004.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Management Discussion is designed to provide readers with a view of the company's results and certain factors that may affect future prospects from the perspective of
the company's management. Within the Management Discussion Snapshot, the key messages and details will give readers the ability to quickly assess the most important drivers of performance within this
brief overview.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Management Discussion reflects the company's continued and improving strength in providing broad client solutions, as opposed to a "piece parts" conglomeration of many
hardware, software and services businesses. The Description of the Business on page 13, Results of Continuing Operations on page 17, Financial Position on page 23, and Looking Forward on page 28
sections, all are written from the perspective of the consolidated entity. Detailed analysis for each of the company's segments is also included and appears on pages 21 to 23.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Global
Financing is a business segment within the company, that is managed on an arm's-length basis and measured as if it were a standalone entity. A separate Global
Financing section beginning on page 35 is not included in the consolidated perspective that is referred to above. This section is separately presented given this segment's unique impact on the
company's financial condition and leverage.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
selected reference to constant currency in the Management Discussion is made so that the financial results can be viewed without the impacts of changing foreign currency
exchange rates and therefore facilitates a comparative view of business growth. The percentages reported in the financial tables throughout the Management Discussion are calculated from the underlying
whole-dollar numbers. See "Currency Rate Fluctuations" on page 33 for additional information. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>HELPFUL HINTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Organization of Information  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>This
Management Discussion section provides the reader of the financial statements with a narrative on the company's financial results. It contains the results of operations
for each segment of the business, followed by a description of the company's financial position, as well as certain employee data. It is useful to read the Management Discussion in conjunction with
note&nbsp;x, "Segment Information," on pages 87 through 91.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Pages
40 through 48 include the Consolidated Financial Statements. These statements provide an overview of the company's income and cash flow performance and its financial
position.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
notes follow the Consolidated Financial Statements. Among other things, the notes contain the company's accounting policies (pages 49 to 55), detailed information on
specific items within the financial statements, certain contingencies and commitments (pages 69 to 71), and the results of each IBM segment (pages 87 through 91). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>11</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=4,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=257202,FOLIO='11',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CG2534A.;35',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2005;11:34' -->
<A NAME="page_cg2534_1_12"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>SUBSEQUENT EVENT  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to the company's press release and Form&nbsp;8-K filing on January&nbsp;18, 2005, announcing 2004 fourth quarter and full year
financial results, the company conducted a review of agreements for sales of third-party hardware in Japan. As a result of this review, the company determined that certain IBM Japan employees acted
improperly and inconsistently with the company's policies and practices. The company is taking appropriate disciplinary action. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Therefore,
the company has reduced full year Global Services revenue and cost by $260&nbsp;million. The previously announced 2004 fourth quarter financial results included
$50&nbsp;million of this adjustment. The additional $210&nbsp;million adjustment is considered a Type 1 subsequent event under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and must be reflected
in the company's 2004 financial statements. As a result, the company has reduced Global Services revenue and cost by $75&nbsp;million, $55&nbsp;million, and $80&nbsp;million in the first, second
and third quarters of 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
was no reduction made to the company's gross profit dollars, income from continuing operations or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;31, 2002, the company sold its hard disk drive (HDD) business to Hitachi, Ltd. (Hitachi). The HDD business was accounted for as a discontinued
operation under GAAP which requires that the income statement and cash flow information be reformatted to separate the divested business from the company's continuing operations. See pages&nbsp;60
and 61 for additional information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=3><B>Management Discussion Snapshot  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>CONTINUING OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, the company demonstrated that it could extend its leadership in a growth environment. The company delivered revenue growth of 8.0&nbsp;percent and
diluted earnings per share growth of 13.8&nbsp;percent. The increase in the company's Income from continuing operations and diluted earnings per share from continuing operations as compared to 2003
was primarily due to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Improving
demand associated with the moderate expansion of the economy and continued market share gains for zSeries and xSeries server products
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Continued
operational improvements in the Microelectronics business
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Continued
demand growth in emerging countries
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Favorable
impact of currency translation </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
increase in revenue in 2004 as compared to 2003 was primarily due to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Improved
demand in Global Services and key industry sectors
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Improving
demand associated with the moderate expansion of the economy and continued market share gains for zSeries, xSeries and pSeries server products, as well as
increased revenue for personal computers
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Continued
demand growth in emerging countries (up over 25&nbsp;percent) and in Business Performance Transformation Services (up approximately 45&nbsp;percent)
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Favorable
impact of currency translation </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
regard to the way that management reviews the business, as-reported and constant currency revenue trends were positive for all of the company's segments (except Global
Financing), geographies and industry sectors. See pages 17 and 18 for the summary trend rates on an as-reported and constant currency basis, as well as information for each segment on
pages 21 to 23. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
consolidated gross profit margin was relatively flat versus 2003, increasing 0.4 points. An improvement in Hardware margins (1.8 points) contributed 0.5 points to the overall margin
improvement. In addition, Global Financing margin improved 4.2 points compared to 2003, however, this improvement had an immaterial impact on the company's overall margin due to the size of the
segment. These improvements were partially offset by Global Services and Software&#151;while margins in these segments were generally flat year-to-year, the mix of these
segments slightly impacted the overall company margin. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
expense and other income increased in 2004 versus 2003 due primarily to increased retirement-related plan costs, including the $320&nbsp;million charge due to the partial
settlement of certain legal claims against the company's IBM Personal Pension Plan (PPP), and unfavorable currency translation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Overall,
retirement-related plan costs increased $1,082&nbsp;million versus 2003, impacting both gross margin and expense. See note&nbsp;w, "Retirement-Related Benefits" on pages 78
through 86 for additional information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
provision for income taxes resulted in an effective tax rate of 29.8&nbsp;percent for 2004, compared with the 2003 effective tax rate of 30.0&nbsp;percent. The 0.2 point decrease
in the effective tax rate in 2004 was
primarily due to the tax effect of the settlement of certain pension claims in the third quarter of 2004 (highlighted above). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>12</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=5,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=1010035,FOLIO='12',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CG2534A.;35',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2005;11:34' -->
<A NAME="page_cg2534_1_13"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
regard to Assets, approximately $3.6&nbsp;billion of the increase relates to the impact of currency translation. The remaining increase primarily consists of an increase in Cash
and cash equivalents, an increase in Goodwill associated with recent acquisitions and increased Prepaid pension assets. The increases were partially offset by lower financing receivables and lower
deferred tax assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
additional information, see the Year in Review section on pages 17 to 26. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global
Financing debt decreased, but the company's Global Financing debt-to-equity ratio remained flat at 6.9 to 1 and within the company's targeted range. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global
Services signings were $43&nbsp;billion in 2004 as compared to $55&nbsp;billion in 2003. The Global Services backlog is estimated to be $111&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2004 versus $120&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2003. For additional information, see Global Services Signings on page 29. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Looking
forward, the company's longer-term financial model targets earnings per share to grow at a low double-digit rate with revenue growth in the
mid-to-high single digits, continued productivity driven margin improvement, and effective capital deployment for acquisitions and common stock repurchase. The company's
ability to meet these objectives depends on a number of factors, including those outlined on page 17 and on pages 69 to 71. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=3><B>Description of Business  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Please refer to IBM's Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K filed on February&nbsp;24, 2005, with the Securities and Exchange Commission
(SEC) for a more detailed version of this Description of Business, especially the detailed "Significant Factors Affecting IBM's Business" section. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM
is an innovation-based business serving the needs of enterprises and institutions worldwide. It defines innovation as the intersection of business insight and technological
invention. IBM seeks to deliver client success&#151;in whatever ways its clients define success&#151;by giving them differentiating capabilities that provide unique competitive
advantage. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;By
helping its clients redesign their business processes and organizational structure, enabled by new operating environments, IBM helps them to become on demand businesses. IBM defines
an on demand business as an enterprise whose business processes are responsive to any demand, opportunity or threat; integrated end-to-end across the company; and capable of
integrating fluidly across extended business ecosystems of partners, suppliers and clients. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM
first described this new model and set of capabilities in 2002, believing they represent the current evolution of information technology architectures and of business and
institutional models. IBM calls this architecture the On Demand Operating Environment: an infrastructure based on industry-wide standards (commonly referred to as "open standards"), rather
than on proprietary technologies. In IBM's view, an enterprise's investment in such an infrastructure provides both superior returns and maximum freedom of interoperability and action. Standards have
become a core element of IBM's overall strategy and impact all of our unit strategies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
shift to standards-based technologies has been bolstered significantly in recent years by the rapid growth of the "open source" software movement, a result of large-scale
collaboration among members of the worldwide developer and business communities. Examples include the Linux operating system, the Eclipse computing platform and the Java programming language. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM's
clients include many different kinds of enterprises, from sole proprietorships to the world's largest organizations, governments and companies representing every major industry and
endeavor. Over the last decade, IBM has exited or greatly de-emphasized its involvement in consumer markets and divested itself of other noncore businesses to concentrate on the enterprise
market. In IBM's view, opportunities in the enterprise market are superior&#151;representing approximately two-thirds of the IT industry's revenue. As a result, IBM has made
acquisitions and invested in emerging business opportunities important to its enterprise clients. Many of these investments have grown into multibillion dollar businesses in their own right, and are
now contributing to IBM's growth. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
majority of the company's enterprise business, which excludes the company's original equipment manufacturer (OEM) technology business, occurs in industries that are broadly grouped
into six sectors around which the company's go-to-market strategies, and sales and distribution activities are organized: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Financial
Services: Banking, Financial Markets, Insurance </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Public:
Education, Government, Healthcare, Life Sciences </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Industrial:
Aerospace, Automotive, Defense, Chemical and Petroleum, Electronics </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Distribution:
Consumer Products, Retail, Travel, Transportation </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Communications:
Telecommunications, Media and Entertainment, Energy and Utilities </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Small
and Medium Business: Mainly companies with less than 1,000 employees </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>THE IT INDUSTRY AND IBM'S STRATEGY  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM operates in the IT industry, which comprises three principal categories: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Business
Value </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Infrastructure
Value </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Component
Value </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM
has realized and continues to see a shift in revenue and profit growth from Component Value to Infrastructure Value and Business Value, where revenue and profit potential are thought
to be greatest in the years ahead. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>13</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=6,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=362235,FOLIO='13',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CG2534A.;35',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2005;11:34' -->
<A NAME="page_cg2534_1_14"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Business Value  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company helps its clients transform their businesses and gain competitive advantage by applying its skills and experience to business performance challenges
specific to the client's industry or across industries and processes. The company enters into long-term relationships and creates solutions for clients, driving on demand business
innovation, on its own or in partnership with other companies. The company draws upon its broad product and service offerings, including Business Consulting Services, IBM Research, industry-leading
middleware, and its deep experience in systems and technology design. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> CAPABILITIES  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Business Consulting Services (BCS).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Delivery of value to clients through consulting services for client relationship
management, financial management, human capital, business strategy and change, and supply chain management, as well as application innovation and the transformation of business processes and
operations. (Global Services) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Business Performance Management (BPM).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Enables companies to visualize end-to-end processes across
business and IT systems, analyze execution in real time against goals, and make adjustments as needed. IBM offers consulting, services and middleware to simulate and monitor business processes, and
provides customers with real-time analysis of the underlying IT systems carrying out those processes. (Software) </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Business Transformation Outsourcing (BTO).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Delivers improved business results to clients through the continual strategic
change and the operation and transformation of the client's business processes, applications and infrastructure. (Global Services) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Center for Business Optimization (CBO).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Helps clients continually optimize their business performance by drawing upon massive
amounts of real-time data, advanced analytical methods, business expertise and deep computing power. (Global Services) </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Customer Financing.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Lease and loan financing to external and internal clients for terms generally between two and five years.
(Global Financing) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Engineering&nbsp;&amp; Technology Services (E&amp;TS).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>System and component design services, strategic outsourcing of clients'
design teams, and technology and manufacturing consulting services. (Systems and Technology Group) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>On Demand Innovation Services (ODIS).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>IBM Research scientists work with BCS consultants to analyze and solve clients' most
intractable business challenges. ODIS offers a number of cross-industry micropractices with deep expertise including mobile enablement and information mining. (Global Services and IBM Research) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Software and services to meet industry-specific needs.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Solutions and applications built on an on demand, standards-based
infrastructure to transform a process that is unique to specific industries. (Multiple IBM segments) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Business Performance Transformation Services (BPTS).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Helps clients transform their spending on business processes, namely
Selling, General and Administrative and Research and Development. BPTS requires advanced technology and deep expertise in industry and/or specific functions like Human Resources (HR), logistics,
payroll, sales, customer services and procurement, to result in holistic improvement for the performance and success of a business, including efficiency of individual processes and their combined
effort. BPTS solutions are delivered to clients by several of the company's business areas: BTO, E&amp;TS, Strategy and Change Consulting and BPM. (Multiple IBM segments) </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Infrastructure Value  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Infrastructure Value includes systems, such as high-volume servers; middleware software that can interconnect disparate operating systems and
applications with data; storage networks; and devices. It also refers to such services as infrastructure management&#151;whether on the client's premises or managed remotely at IBM's own
facilities&#151;and consulting about how to improve and strengthen the infrastructure and realize greater return on investment in it. Central to IBM's approach for building value in the
infrastructure category is its support of open standards and its active promotion of Linux and other open source platforms, which help IBM's clients control costs and allow them to benefit from the
latest advances created by development communities around the world. IBM's strategic objective is to deliver open and integrated offerings and expand partnerships. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> CAPABILITIES  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Application Management Services.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Application development, management, maintenance and support services for packaged software,
as well as custom and legacy applications. (Global Services) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Commercial financing.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Short-term inventory and accounts receivable financing to dealers and remarketers of IT
products. (Global Financing) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>DB2 information management software.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Advanced database and content management software solutions that enable clients to
leverage information on demand. (Software) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>e-business Hosting Services.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Solutions for the management of clients' Web-based infrastructure and
business applications, as well as a growing portfolio of industry-specific independent software vendor (ISV) solutions that are delivered as a service. (Global Services) </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Integrated Technology Services (ITS).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Design, implementation and maintenance of clients' technology infrastructures. (Global
Services) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Lotus software.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Collaboration and messaging software that allows a company's employees, clients, vendors and partners to
engage in real-time and asynchronous communication and knowledge management. (Software) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Personal computers.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Notebook and desktop computers featuring ThinkVantage Technologies that provide enterprises and end users
with increased productivity and cost-effectiveness. (Personal Systems Group) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Printing Systems.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Production print solutions, on demand print-related solutions, enterprise workgroup print technologies, and
print management software and services. (Personal Systems Group) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Rational software.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Integrated tools designed to improve an organization's software development processes and capabilities.
(Software) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Remarketing.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The sale and lease of used equipment (primarily sourced from the conclusion of lease transactions) to new or
existing clients. (Global Financing) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Retail Store Solutions.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Point-of-sale retail checkout equipment, software and solutions. (Personal
Systems Group) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Servers.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>IBM eServer systems using IBM operating systems (zSeries and iSeries), as well as AIX, the IBM UNIX operating system
(pSeries) and the Microsoft Windows operating system (xSeries). All servers can also run Linux, a key open source operating system. (Systems and Technology Group and Software) </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>14</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_cg2534_1_15"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Storage.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Data storage products, including disk, tape and storage area networks. (Systems and Technology Group) </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Strategic Outsourcing Services (SO).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Competitive cost advantages through the outsourcing of processes and operations. (Global
Services) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Tivoli software.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Software for infrastructure management, including security, change, configuration, job scheduling, storage
capability, performance and availability. (Software) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>WebSphere software.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Management of a wide variety of business processes using open standards to interconnect applications,
data and operating systems. (Software) </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Component Value  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Component Value includes advanced semiconductor development and manufacturing for IBM's server and storage offerings, and services, technology and licenses
provided to OEMs&nbsp;that create and market products requiring advanced chips and other core technology elements. IBM leverages components for infrastructure value, while continuing to participate
in selected markets, focusing on key industry partners. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> CAPABILITIES  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASICs).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Manufacturing of customized semiconductor products for clients. (Systems and
Technology Group) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Advanced Foundry.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Integrated supply chain services and a full suite of semiconductor manufacturing services using either a
client's or IBM's design. (Systems and Technology Group) </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Standard products and custom microprocessors.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Semiconductors designed and manufactured primarily based upon IBM's PowerPC
architecture. (Systems and Technology Group) </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>BUSINESS SEGMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Organizationally, the company's major operations comprise a Global Services segment; a Systems and Technology Group; a Personal Systems Group; a Software segment;
a Global Financing segment; and an Enterprise Investments segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Global Services </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>is a critical component of the company's strategy of providing insight and solutions to clients. While solutions often
include industry-leading IBM software and hardware, other suppliers' products are also used if a client solution requires it. Global Services outsourcing contracts as well as BCS contracts range from
less than one year to ten years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Systems and Technology Group </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>provides IBM's clients with business solutions requiring advanced computing power and storage capabilities.
More than half of the Systems and Technology Group's eServer and Storage Systems sales transactions are through business partners; approximately 40&nbsp;percent are direct to end-user
clients, more than half of which are through the Web at ibm.com. In addition, the group provides leading semiconductor technology and products, packaging solutions and engineering technology services
to OEM clients (approximately 14&nbsp;percent of Systems and Technology Group revenue) and for IBM's own advanced technology needs. While appropriately not reported as external revenue, hardware is
also deployed to support Global Services solutions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Personal Systems Group </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>includes sales of personal computers, business and computing solutions for retail stores and advanced printing
capabilities for large enterprise clients and small and medium-sized businesses. In December&nbsp;2004, it was announced that Lenovo Group Limited, the largest information technology company in
China, will acquire IBM's Personal Computing Division. This transaction is expected to close in the second quarter of 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Software </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>consists primarily of middleware and operating systems software. Middleware software enables clients to integrate systems,
processes and applications across their enterprises. Middleware is designed to be the underlying support for applications provided by independent software vendors (ISVs), who build industry- or
process-specific applications according to open industry standards. Operating systems are the engines that run computers. Approximately 40&nbsp;percent of external Software revenue relates to
one-time charge (OTC) arrangements,whereby the client pays one up-front payment for a lifetime license. The remaining annuity revenue consists of both maintenance revenue sold with OTC
arrangements, as well as revenue from software sold on a monthly license charge (MLC) arrangement. Typically, arrangements for the sale of OTC software include one year of maintenance. The client can
also purchase ongoing maintenance after the first year, which includes product upgrades and technical support. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Global Financing </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>is described on pages 35 to 39. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Enterprise Investments </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>develops and provides industry-specific IT solutions supporting the Hardware, Software and Global Services segments
of the company. Primary product lines include product life cycle management software and document processing technologies. Product life cycle management software primarily serves the Industrial sector
and helps clients manage the development and manufacturing of their products. Document processor products service the Financial Services sector and include products that enable electronic banking. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>IBM WORLDWIDE ORGANIZATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following three company-wide organizations play key roles in IBM's delivery of value to its clients: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Sales&nbsp;&amp;
Distribution Organization and related sales channels

Development and Intellectual Property
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Integrated
Supply Chain </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>15</FONT></P>

<UL>
