<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ci2534_1_16"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Sales&nbsp;&amp; Distribution Organization  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With a comprehensive knowledge of IBM's business and infrastructure solutions, as well as the individual products, technologies and services offered by IBM and
its network of business partners, the company's global team of account representatives and solutions professionals gain a deep understanding of each client's organizational, infrastructure and
industry-specific needs to determine the best approach for addressing the client's critical business and IT challenges. These professionals work in integrated teams with IBM consultants and technology
representatives, combining their deep skills and expertise to deliver high-value solutions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>INTERNAL ROUTES-TO-MARKET  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Global Services</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> consultants focused on selling end-to-end solutions for large, complex
business challenges. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Hardware and software brand specialists</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> selling IBM products as parts of discrete technology decisions, typically to
"self-integrating" IT departments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>ibm.com</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> Online and telephone sales and assistance operations handle basic commodity transactions for large enterprises and
small-to-medium businesses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>BUSINESS PARTNERS ROUTES-TO-MARKET  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global/major independent software vendors (ISVs).</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ISVs deliver business process or industry-specific applications and, in
doing so, often influence the sale of IBM hardware, middleware and services. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global/major systems integrators (SIs).</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SIs identify business problems and design solutions when Global Services is not the
preferred systems integrator; they also sell computing infrastructures from IBM and its competitors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional ISVs and SIs.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SIs identify the business problems, and ISVs deliver business process or industry-specific
applications to medium-sized and large businesses requiring IBM computing infrastructure offerings. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Solutions providers, resellers and distributors.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Resellers sell IBM platforms and value-added services as part of a discrete
technology platform decision to clients wanting third-party assistance. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Research, Development and Intellectual Property  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM's research and development (R&amp;D) operations differentiate IBM from its competitors. IBM annually spends approximately $5 - 6&nbsp;billion for
R&amp;D, including capitalized software costs, focusing its investments in high-growth opportunities. As a result of innovations in these and other areas, IBM was once again awarded more U.S.
patents in 2004 than any other company. This marks the 12th year in a row that IBM achieved this distinction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to producing world-class hardware and software products, IBM innovations are a major differentiator in providing solutions for the company's clients through its growing
services activities. The company's investments in R&amp;D also result in intellectual property (IP) income. Some of IBM's technological breakthroughs are used exclusively in IBM products, while others are
used by the company's licensees for their products when that new technology is not strategic to IBM's business goals. A third group is both used internally and licensed externally. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to these IP income sources, the company also generates value from its patent portfolio through cross-licensing arrangements and IP licensed in divestiture transactions. The
value of these other two sources is not readily apparent in the financial results and Consolidated Statement of Earnings, because income on cross-licensing arrangements is recorded only to the extent
that cash is received. The value received by IBM for IP involving the sale of a business is included in the overall gain or loss from the divestiture, not in the separately displayed IP income amounts
in financial results and Consolidated Statement of Earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2005, IBM announced that it would pledge 500 of its patents for use by the open computing community, representing a major shift in the way IBM manages and deploys its
intellectual property portfolio. IBM's intent is to help form an industry-wide "patent commons," in which patents are used to establish a platform for further innovation in areas of broad
interest to information technology developers and users. The pledge is applicable to any individual, community or company working on or using software that meets the Open Source Initiative (OSI)
definition of open source software. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Integrated Supply Chain  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Just as IBM works to transform its clients' supply chains for greater efficiency and responsiveness to market conditions, IBM has undertaken a large-scale
initiative to recast its own integrated supply chain as an on demand business operation, turning what had previously been an expense to be managed into a strategic advantage for the company and,
ultimately, improved delivery and outcomes for its clients. IBM spends approximately $41&nbsp;billion annually through its supply chain, procuring materials and services around the world. The
company's supply, manufacturing and distribution operations are integrated in one operating unit that has reduced inventories, improved response to marketplace opportunities and external risks and
converted fixed to variable costs. Simplifying and streamlining internal operations has improved sales force productivity and processes and thereby the experiences of the company's clients when
working with IBM. Because some of the cost savings this unit generates are passed along to clients, they will not always result in a visible gross margin improvement in the company's Consolidated
Statement of Earnings. While these efforts are largely concerned with product manufacturing and delivery, IBM is also applying supply chain principles to service delivery across its solutions and
services lines of business. To accomplish this, IBM is creating a new labor resource management system&#151;based on a uniform taxonomy of skills&#151;that will enable the organization
to more efficiently match its labor resources to the needs of IBM clients, deploy the right expertise quickly, and create a better short-term and long-term balance of labor
supply and demand by comparing the demands of the market against the database of available skills. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to its own manufacturing operations, the company uses a number of contract manufacturing (CM) companies around the world to manufacture IBM-designed products. The
use of CM companies is intended to generate cost efficiencies and reduce time-to-market for certain IBM products. Some of the company's relationships with CM companies are
exclusive. The company has key relationships with Sanmina-SCI for the manufacture of some Intel-based products and with Solectron for a significant portion of the manufacturing operations
of Global Asset Recovery Services-an operation of Global Financing that restores end-of-lease personal computers and other IT equipment for resale. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>16</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=9,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=865634,FOLIO='16',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CI2534A.;32',USER='CNAPOLE',CD='24-FEB-2005;11:43' -->
<A NAME="page_ci2534_1_17"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>KEY BUSINESS DRIVERS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following are some of the key drivers of the company's business. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Economic Environment and Corporate IT Spending Budgets  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If overall demand for hardware, software and services changes, whether due to general economic conditions or a shift in corporate buying patterns, sales
performance could be impacted. IBM's diverse
portfolio of products and offerings is designed to gain market share in strong and weak economic climates. The company accomplishes this by not only having a mix of offerings with
long-term cash and income streams as well as cyclical transaction-based sales, but also by continually developing competitive products and solutions and effectively managing a skilled
resource base. IBM continues to transform itself to take advantage of shifting demand trends, focusing on client or industry-specific solutions, business performance and open standards. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Internal Business Transformation and Efficiency Initiatives  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM continues to drive greater productivity and cost savings as it transforms itself into an on demand enterprise. This includes the internal supply chain
initiatives discussed above, as well as driving collaboration across the IBM enterprise to stimulate innovation and drive growth. Transformation efforts are improving the company's management of its
costs worldwide: rebalancing of skills, optimizing its workforce to drive growth, keeping the company's compensation programs competitive, and creating a cost-efficient and cutting-edge IT
infrastructure to support its transformation. IBM is extending its supply chain initiatives to labor costs and other internal processes. Continued success in this area will impact the company's cost
structure improvements, as well as the amount of competitive leverage it can apply by passing savings along to clients. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Innovation Initiatives  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IBM invests for new and innovative capabilities, products and services. IBM has been moving away from commoditized categories of the IT industry and into areas in
which it can differentiate itself through innovation and by leveraging its investments in R&amp;D. Examples include IBM's leadership position in the design and fabrication of ASICs; the design of smaller,
faster and energy-efficient semiconductor devices; the design of "grid" computing networks that allow computers to share processing power; the transformation and integration of business processes; and
the company's efforts to advance open technology standards and to engage with governments, academia, think tanks and nongovernmental organizations on emerging trends in technology, society and
culture. In the highly competitive IT industry, with large diversified competitors as well as smaller and nimble single-technology competitors, IBM's ability to continue its cutting-edge
innovation is critical to maintaining and increasing market share. IBM is managing this risk by more closely linking its R&amp;D organization to industry-specific and client-specific needs, as discussed
in Description of Business&#151;IBM Worldwide Organizations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Open Standards  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The broad adoption of open standards is essential to the computing model for an on demand business and is a significant driver of collaborative innovation across
all industries. Without interoperability among all manner of computing platforms, the integration of any client's internal systems, applications and processes remains a monumental and expensive task.
The broad-based acceptance of open standards&#151;rather than closed, proprietary architectures&#151;also allows the computing infrastructure to more easily absorb (and thus benefit
from) new technical innovations. IBM is committed to fostering open standards because they are vital to the On Demand Operating Environment, and because their acceptance will expand growth
opportunities across the entire business services and IT industry. There are a number of competitors in the IT industry with significant resources and investments who are committed to closed and
proprietary platforms as a way to lock
customers into a particular architecture. This competition will result in increased pricing pressure and/or IP claims and proceedings. IBM's support of open standards is evidenced by the enabling of
its products to support open standards such as Linux, and the development of Rational software development tools, which can be used to develop and upgrade any other company's software products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Emerging Business Opportunities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company is continuing to refocus its business on the higher value segments of enterprise computing&#151;providing technology and transformation
services to clients' businesses. Consistent with that focus, the company continues to significantly invest in Emerging Business Opportunities, as a way to drive revenue growth and market share gain.
Areas of investment include strategic acquisitions, primarily in software and services, information-based medicine, on demand retail, sensor and actuator solutions, Business Performance Transformation
Services, key technologies (POWER5 and POWERBlade) and emerging growth countries such as China, Russia, India and Brazil. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=4><B>Year in Review  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue
from all industry sectors increased in 2004 when compared to 2003, reflecting the company's broad capabilities and industry-specific solutions which combine technology and high
value services to solve a client's business or IT problems. These solutions also provide for a longer-term relationship with the client, rather than a transaction-oriented sale. The
Financial Services sector revenue growth was led by financial markets (15&nbsp;percent), banking (9&nbsp;percent) and insurance (8&nbsp;percent). The Communications sector had strong revenue
growth in Telecommunications (15&nbsp;percent), while the Distribution sector was led by the retail industry (12&nbsp;percent). The Small&nbsp;&amp; Medium business sector increased as the company
continued to roll out new products under the Express label that are designed and priced specifically for customers in the 100 to 1,000 employee segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue
across all geographies increased in 2004 when compared to 2003. In the Americas, U.S. (6&nbsp;percent) and Canada (9&nbsp;percent) revenue grew as did Latin America
(12&nbsp;percent), notably Brazil, which grew at 15&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Within
Europe/Middle East/Africa, Eastern Europe, the Nordic countries, Spain (7&nbsp;percent) and France (3&nbsp;percent) had revenue growth, while the U.K. (2&nbsp;percent),
Germany (3&nbsp;percent) and Italy (8&nbsp;percent) declined after adjusting for currency. Asia Pacific had strong growth in 2004, led by China, which grew at 25&nbsp;percent, and the ASEAN
region (17&nbsp;percent), while Japan, which is about 60&nbsp;percent of Asia Pacific's revenue, also had growth of 5&nbsp;percent. Collectively, as a result of the company's targeted
investments, the emerging countries of China, Russia (75&nbsp;percent), India (45&nbsp;percent) and Brazil had revenue growth over 25&nbsp;percent in 2004 to over $4.0&nbsp;billion in revenue. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;OEM
revenue increased in 2004 versus 2003 due primarily to continued strong growth in the company's Engineering &amp; Technology Services business and improved operational performance in the
Microelectronics business. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in Global Services revenue was driven by SO as it continued its steady growth. BCS and ITS revenue also increased. Maintenance revenue increased due to the favorable impact
of currency movements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, significant progress was made in the company's relatively new BPTS offerings (see page&nbsp;14) where revenue grew approximately 45&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
Hardware, Systems and Technology Group, revenue increased as zSeries servers, xSeries servers, pSeries servers and Engineering&nbsp;&amp; Technology Services increased. zSeries' strong
performance resulted from clients adding new workload to the mainframe as they build their on demand infrastructures. xSeries had strong growth, driven by its leadership in Blades. pSeries server
revenue increased as the company's POWER5 technology was well received by customers in 2004. Demand for the company's
Engineering&nbsp;&amp; Technology services continued to be strong. Storage Systems revenue increased due to greater demand for external midrange disk and tape products, offset by decreases in
high-end disk products. Microelectronics revenue increased due primarily to improved yields and increased output in the 300 millimeter factory. iSeries server revenue declined as the
transition to POWER5 technology is taking longer than previous cycles. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Personal
Systems Group revenue increased in 2004, driven by strong performance worldwide by the company's ThinkPad mobile computers. Retail store solutions also delivered strong revenue
growth in 2004 due to continued demand for its products as well as the acquisition of Productivity Solutions&nbsp;Inc. in November&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Software
revenue increased due to improved demand for Data Management products, Tivoli software products, the WebSphere family of products and Rational products. Operating Systems
revenue increased slightly primarily due to favorable currency translation. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decline in Global Financing revenue in 2004 versus 2003 was primarily driven by lower used equipment sales. See pages&nbsp;35 to 39 for additional information regarding Global
Financing results. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>Total</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>37.4</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><B>%</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>37.0</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>0.4</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;pts.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
modest decline in Global Services gross profit margin was due to continued investment in on demand infrastructure and business transformation capabilities, and less contribution from
the higher margin Maintenance business. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in Hardware margins was primarily due to yield improvements in the Microelectronics business and margin improvements in zSeries servers, xSeries servers, storage products
and personal computers, as well as the impact of certain hedging transactions (see "Anticipated Royalties and Cost Transactions" on page&nbsp;66). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Software margin increased due to growth in software revenue, as well as productivity improvements in the company's support and distribution models. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in the Global Financing margin was primarily driven by a mix change towards higher margin financing revenue and away from lower margin used equipment sales and improved
margins from financing revenue. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
cost savings generated by the company's supply chain initiatives also contributed to the company's overall margin improvement, but as discussed on page&nbsp;16, the company has
passed a portion of the savings to clients to improve competitive leadership and gain market share in key industry sectors. In addition, an increase in retirement-related plan costs of approximately
$490&nbsp;million compared to 2003 impacted overall segment margins. See segment discussion on pages&nbsp;21 to 23 for further details on gross profit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
expense and other income increased 8.4&nbsp;percent (5.4&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency) in 2004 versus 2003. The increase was primarily due to higher retirement-related
plan costs, Research, development and engineering expense and the effect of currency translation on expense. For additional information regarding the increase in Total expense and other income, see
the following analyses by category: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
SG&amp;A expense increased 8.6&nbsp;percent (5.1&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency). The increase was primarily driven by increased expense for retirement-related plan costs of
approximately $515&nbsp;million, which included a one-time charge of $320&nbsp;million related to the partial settlement of certain legal claims against the company's PPP (see
pages&nbsp;20 and 21 for further information on retirement-related benefits), unfavorable currency translation of $626&nbsp;million, and provisions for certain litigation-related expenses of
$125&nbsp;million in 2004. These increases were partially offset by lower workforce reductions and lower Advertising and promotional expense. The amount of Workforce reductions&#151;ongoing
will vary from year to year depending upon the required skills, competitive environment and economic conditions. In addition, Bad debt expense declined primarily due to lower reserve requirements
associated with the improvement in economic conditions and improved credit quality, as well as the lower asset base of the Global Financing receivables portfolio (see page&nbsp;37). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>NM&#151;Not
Meaningful </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
(income) and expense was income of $23&nbsp;million in 2004 versus expense of $238&nbsp;million in 2003. The improvement was primarily driven by increased gains from various
asset sales including certain real estate transactions in 2004 versus 2003, additional Interest income generated by the company in 2004 and other nonrecurring gains/settlements increasing in 2004 when
compared to 2003. The Foreign currency transaction losses relate primarily to losses on certain hedge contracts offset by gains on the settlement of foreign currency receivables and payables. See
pages&nbsp;33 and 34 for additional discussion of currency impacts on the company's financial results. </FONT></P>

(approximately $240&nbsp;million). In addition, RD&amp;E expense increased due to spending related to the POWER5 technology initiatives (approximately $140&nbsp;million), increased spending on new
storage products (approximately $50&nbsp;million), and higher retirement-related plan costs (approximately $77&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">

<P><FONT SIZE=2>NM&#151;Not
Meaningful </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=13,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=307660,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CI2534A.;32',USER='CNAPOLE',CD='24-FEB-2005;11:43' -->
<A NAME="page_ci2534_1_21"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Overall,
retirement-related plan costs increased $1,082&nbsp;million versus 2003. On December&nbsp;31, 2003, the company lowered its PPP discount rate from 6.75&nbsp;percent to
6.0&nbsp;percent which increased pre-tax cost and expense by almost $200&nbsp;million in 2004. In addition, the 2004 results include a charge of $320&nbsp;million due to the partial
settlement of certain legal claims against the company's PPP. The 2004 results were also affected by changes in the market value of plan assets as well as similar trends in the company's other defined
benefits pension plans that contributed to the increase in costs. See note&nbsp;w, "Retirement-Related Benefits" on pages&nbsp;78 through 86 for additional information. The
year-to-year increase impacted gross margin, SG&amp;A and RD&amp;E by approximately $490&nbsp;million, $515&nbsp;million and $77&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Provision for Income Taxes  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The provision for income taxes resulted in an effective tax rate of 29.8&nbsp;percent for 2004, compared with the 2003 effective tax rate of
30.0&nbsp;percent. The 0.2&nbsp;point decrease in the effective tax rate in 2004 was primarily due to the tax effect of the settlement of certain pension claims in the third quarter of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
average number of common shares outstanding assuming dilution was lower by 47.2&nbsp;million shares in 2004 versus 2003. The decrease was primarily the result of the company's
common share repurchase program. See note&nbsp;n, "Stockholders' Equity Activity," on page&nbsp;69 for additional information regarding the common share activities. Also see note&nbsp;t,
"Earnings Per Share of Common Stock," on page&nbsp;77. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>SEGMENT DETAILS  </B></FONT></P>

28. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global
Services revenue increased 8.4&nbsp;percent (3.1&nbsp;percent adjusted for currency). SO continued to demonstrate its competitive advantage in delivering on demand solutions
by leveraging its business transformational skills and its scale during 2004. Each geography continued year-to-year growth, with seven consecutive quarters of double-digit
growth in Europe/Middle East/Africa, excluding currency benefits. Within SO, e-business Hosting Services, an offering that provides Web infrastructure and application management as an
Internet based service, continued its pattern of revenue growth. ITS revenue, which excludes Maintenance, increased driven by growth in Business Continuity and Recovery Services of 29&nbsp;percent,
partially offset by the reduction for sales of third-party hardware in Japan. (See page&nbsp;12, "Subsequent Event" for additional information.) BCS revenue increased driven by strong growth in BTO.
BCS continued to improve its revenue growth rate at constant currency in every quarter of the year. Maintenance revenue increased primarily driven by favorable impacts of currency movements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Global Services gross profit dollars increased primarily due to the corresponding increase in revenue. The gross profit margin declined due to investment in on demand infrastructure
and business transformation capabilities, as well as a lower mix of Maintenance revenue (12&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 13&nbsp;percent in 2003), which has a higher gross profit margin than the
other categories of Global Services revenue. These declines were partially offset by improved profitability in BCS driven by improved utilization, reduced overhead structure and an improved labor mix. </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="57%"><FONT SIZE=2>Retail Store Solutions</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>17.6</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="57%"><FONT SIZE=2>Printer Systems</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>(7.6</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Systems
and Technology Group revenue increased 8.8&nbsp;percent (5.2&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency). zSeries revenue increased due to clients continuing to add new workloads on
the zSeries platform as they build their on demand infrastructures, as well as taking advantage of the capabilities of the z990 server for consolidations. Mainframes remain the platform of choice for
hosting mission-critical transactions as well as for consolidations and infrastructure simplification. The total delivery of zSeries computing power as measured in MIPS (millions of instructions per
second) increased 33&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 2003, offsetting price declines of 23&nbsp;percent per MIPS. xSeries server revenue increased (24&nbsp;percent) due to strong growth in both
high-end and 1&amp;2Way Servers. xSeries-related BladeCenter revenue had strong growth, up over 150&nbsp;percent, as the company is leading and shaping the blade market. In the fourth quarter of 2004,
the company saw strong demand for the new POWERBlade, which can run Windows, Linux and AIX on different servers in the BladeCenter. pSeries server revenue increased reflecting clients' very strong
acceptance of the POWER5 systems. The new pSeries high-end system started shipping in November&nbsp;2004, marking the completion of a top to bottom refresh of the pSeries server product line in just
three months. iSeries server revenue declined driven by lower sales as the transition to POWER5 is taking longer than in previous cycles, as customers must transition their operating environment to
the new level. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Storage
Systems revenue increased slightly due to increased demand for external midrange disk (13&nbsp;percent) and tape products (9&nbsp;percent). These increases were partially
offset by decreases in high end disk products (18&nbsp;percent) as clients anticipated the shipment of the company's new POWER5 high-end storage product which will ship in the first quarter of 2005.
Engineering &amp; Technology Services had strong revenue growth due to increased design and technical services contracts and Microelectronics revenue increased modestly as yields in the 300 millimeter
plant improved. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Personal
Systems Group revenue increased 12.4&nbsp;percent (8.3&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency). The increase was driven by strong performance worldwide by the company's
ThinkPad mobile computer (22&nbsp;percent). Desktop personal computer revenue increased (4&nbsp;percent) in 2004 when compared to 2003 due primarily to favorable currency movements. Retail Store
Solutions revenue increased due to strong demand for the company's products and the acquisition of Productivity Solutions&nbsp;Inc. in November&nbsp;2003. This acquisition drove 6.9 points of the
unit's revenue growth in 2004. Printing Systems maintenance revenue declined due to lower annuity-based revenue on a declining installed base. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hardware
gross profit dollars and gross profit margin increased in 2004 versus 2003. The increase in gross profit dollars was primarily driven by the increase in Hardware revenue. The
increase in the overall hardware margin was driven by several factors. Improved yields and lower unit costs in the Microelectronics business contributed 0.8 points of the increase. In addition, margin
improvements in zSeries, xSeries and Storage Systems contributed 0.5 points, 0.2 points and 0.1 point, respectively, to the overall margin improvement. These improvements were partially offset by
lower margins in iSeries, pSeries, Retail Store Solutions and Printer Systems, which impacted the overall margin by 0.8 points, 0.3 points, 0.1 point and 0.1 point, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Differences
between the hardware segment gross profit margin and gross profit dollar amounts above and the amounts reported on page&nbsp;19 (and derived from
page&nbsp;40)&nbsp;primarily relate to the impact of certain hedging transactions (see "Anticipated Royalties and Cost Transactions" on page&nbsp;66). The recorded amounts for such impact are
considered unallocated corporate amounts for purposes of measuring the segment's gross margin performance and therefore are not included in the segment results above. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>*</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Reclassified
to conform with 2004 presentation. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Software
revenue increased 5.5&nbsp;percent (0.6&nbsp;percent adjusted for currency). Middleware revenue increased 6.4&nbsp;percent (1.5&nbsp;percent adjusted for currency). The
WebSphere family of software offerings revenue increased 14&nbsp;percent with growth in business integration software (14&nbsp;percent), WebSphere Portal software (12&nbsp;percent) and
application servers (20&nbsp;percent). Data Management revenue increased 7&nbsp;percent with growth of 12&nbsp;percent in DB2 Database software on both the host (13&nbsp;percent) and
distributed platforms (11&nbsp;percent), DB2 Tools (8&nbsp;percent), and distributed enterprise content management software (23&nbsp;percent). Rational software revenue increased
(15&nbsp;percent) with growth across all product areas. Tivoli software revenue increased (15&nbsp;percent), aided by the Candle acquisition, which was completed in the second quarter of 2004.
Tivoli systems management, storage and security software all had revenue growth in 2004 versus 2003. Lotus software revenue increased 3&nbsp;percent and Other Foundation middleware products revenue
also increased 2&nbsp;percent due to favorable currency movements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
system software increased due to growth in xSeries and pSeries, which correlates to the increases in the related server brands. zSeries operating system revenue declined
1&nbsp;percent despite the growth in related hardware volumes due to ongoing software price performance delivered to enterprise clients. iSeries operating system software declined 6&nbsp;percent
in line with related hardware volumes. Overall, operating systems software revenue increased primarily as a result of favorable currency movements. </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="58%"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit margin</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>87.3</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><B>%</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>86.5</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>%</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>0.8</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;pts.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in the Software gross profit dollars and gross profit margin was primarily driven by growth in software revenue due to favorable currency movements, as well as productivity
improvements in the company's support and distribution models. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Global Financing  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See pages&nbsp;35 and 36 for a discussion of Global Financing's revenue and gross profit. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Enterprise Investments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue from Enterprise Investments increased 10.8&nbsp;percent (4.2&nbsp;percent adjusted for currency). Revenue for product life-cycle
management software increased primarily in the automotive and aerospace industries, partially offset by lower hardware revenue (48 percent), primarily for document processors. Gross profit dollars
increased 12.4&nbsp;percent and gross profit margins increased 0.6 points to 44.2&nbsp;percent in 2004 versus 2003. The increase in gross profit dollars was primarily driven by the increase in
revenue. The gross profit margin increase was primarily driven by higher life-cycle management software margins driving 0.8 points of the increase, partially offset by lower margins on
document processors due to discounting, which impacted the overall margin by 0.2 points. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>FINANCIAL POSITION  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Dynamics  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The assets and debt associated with the company's Global Financing business are a significant part of the company's financial condition. Accordingly, although the
financial position amounts appearing below and on pages&nbsp;24 and 25 are the company's consolidated amounts including Global Financing, to the extent the Global Financing business is a major
driver of the consolidated financial position, reference in the narrative section will be made to the separate Global Financing section in this Management Discussion on pages&nbsp;35 to 39. The
amounts appearing in the separate Global Financing section are supplementary data presented to facilitate an understanding of the company's Global Financing business. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Current

$374&nbsp;million primarily driven by new product transitions and increased capacity in the 300 millimeter semiconductor fab. These increases were partially offset by an overall decrease in the
company's current receivables of $787&nbsp;million. The current receivables net decrease was </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=16,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=593236,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CK2534A.;30',USER='MREYES',CD='23-FEB-2005;19:25' -->
<A NAME="page_ck2534_1_24"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>a
combination of several factors: a decline of $1,782&nbsp;million in Short-term financing receivables as collections exceeded new originations; an increase in Other accounts receivable of
$499&nbsp;million as a long-term receivable related to the sale of the HDD business is now reflected as current; and an increase in Notes and accounts receivable-trade of
$496&nbsp;million as a result of favorable currency movements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Current
liabilities increased $2,175&nbsp;million primarily due to a $1,453&nbsp;million increase in Short-term debt, a $984&nbsp;million increase in Accounts payable,
and a $683&nbsp;million increase in Deferred income driven by Global Services business growth in 2004. These increases were partially offset by a decrease of $747&nbsp;million in Taxes payable
primarily due to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) settlement described in note&nbsp;p, "Taxes" on page&nbsp;73, and $331&nbsp;million in Other accrued expenses and liabilities primarily due to
decreases of approximately $160&nbsp;million in restructuring accruals. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
cash provided from operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004 increased $837&nbsp;million as compared to 2003. This increase was driven primarily by increased
income from continuing operations ($835&nbsp;million), the cash generated by the change in Global Financing receivables ($582&nbsp;million) and lower restructuring payments ($462&nbsp;million).
These increases were partially offset by additional pension funding worldwide in 2004 of $1.2&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
investing activities increased by $224&nbsp;million on a year-to-year basis. Net capital spending decreased $190 million on a year-to-year basis. The
primary drivers to the reduction in net capital spending were increased cash from equipment sales of $272&nbsp;million reflecting the cash investments of the company's Microelectronics business
strategic partners, as well as a $25&nbsp;million decrease in the company's internal spending on plant, rental machines and other property. This cash savings was partially offset by an increase of
$107&nbsp;million in capitalized software development. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease in cash used in financing activities of $179&nbsp;million was attributable to less net debt payments of $2,454&nbsp;million, partially offset by higher net payments for
common stock activity of $2,186&nbsp;million, and higher dividend payments of $89&nbsp;million. Within debt, on a net basis, $1,027&nbsp;million of cash was used to pay off debt in 2004 versus
$3,481&nbsp;million. The net cash payments of $1,027&nbsp;million in 2004 were made up of $4,538&nbsp;million of cash payments to settle debt, partially offset by $2,438&nbsp;million of
proceeds from new debt and $1,073&nbsp;million from an increase in short-term borrowings. The higher payments for common stock were driven by increases of approximately
$2,802&nbsp;million in cash payments to repurchase stock which was partially offset by increases of $616&nbsp;million in cash received for stock issued associated with the company's stock option
plan and employee stock purchase plan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in Non-current assets of $2,418&nbsp;million was driven by several factors: an increase of $1,968&nbsp;million in Prepaid pension assets (see note&nbsp;w,
"Retirement-Related Benefits," on pages&nbsp;78 through 86); an increase of $1,516&nbsp;million in Goodwill, driven by acquisitions; and an increase of $486&nbsp;million in Plant, rental
machines and other property&#151;net, driven by currency. These increases were partially offset by a decrease of $1,826&nbsp;million in Investments and sundry assets due to a decrease of
$1,264&nbsp;million in deferred tax assets primarily due to the IRS settlement (see note&nbsp;p, "Taxes" on page&nbsp;73)&nbsp;and $647&nbsp;million in non-current derivatives
due primarily to the reclassification of derivative instruments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long-term
debt declined $2,158&nbsp;million primarily due to the transfer of long-term bonds to short-term debt as these items approach maturity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
non-current liabilities increased $2,826&nbsp;million primarily due to a $1,632&nbsp;million increase in Retirement and nonpension postretirement benefit
obligations, a $380&nbsp;million increase in Deferred income, a $317&nbsp;million increase in Derivative liabilities and a $138&nbsp;million increase in warranty accruals. The increase in the
Retirement and nonpension postretirement benefit obligations was primarily attributable to the required accounting for the unfunded status of the non-U.S. pension plans as described on
page&nbsp;83, as well as pension costs and approximately $544&nbsp;million due to foreign currencies. The increase in Deferred income was driven by Global Services resulting from new contracts
with long-term components. The increase in Derivative liabilities was primarily attributable to the impact of foreign currencies in combination with extending beyond one year the hedging
of anticipated royalties and cost transactions during 2004 (see note&nbsp;l, "Derivatives and Hedging Transactions" on pages&nbsp;65 to 67). The increase in warranty accruals was primarily related
to personal computers resulting from increased volumes. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=17,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=681759,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CK2534A.;30',USER='MREYES',CD='23-FEB-2005;19:25' -->
<A NAME="page_ck2534_1_25"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Debt  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company's funding requirements are continually monitored and strategies are executed to manage the company's overall asset and liability profile.
Additionally, the company maintains sufficient flexibility to access global funding sources as needed. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="83%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=4 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>(Dollars in millions)<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>

2.2&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's total consolidated Stockholders' equity increased $1,883&nbsp;million during 2004 primarily due to an increase in the company's retained earnings driven by net income,
partially offset by the company's ongoing stock repurchase program and higher dividend payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company, in the ordinary course of business, entered into off-balance sheet arrangements as defined by the Securities and Exchange Commission
(SEC) Financial Reporting Release 67 (FRR-67), "Disclosure in Management's Discussion and Analysis about Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations,"
including: certain guarantees, indemnifications and retained interests in assets transferred to an unconsolidated entity for securitization purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None
of these off-balance sheet arrangements either has, or is reasonably likely to have, a material current or future effect on financial condition, changes in financial
condition, revenues or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources. See page&nbsp;31 for the company's contractual obligations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
note&nbsp;o, "Contingencies and Commitments," on page&nbsp;71, for detailed information about the company's guarantees on certain loans and financial commitments, indemnification
arrangements and note&nbsp;j, "Sale and Securitization of Receivables" on page&nbsp;64 for detailed information regarding loans receivable securitization program. </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>*</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>2.7&nbsp;percent
increase adjusting for currency </FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Continuing Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in the company's fourth quarter 2004 Income from continuing operations and diluted earnings per share from continuing operations as compared to the
fourth quarter of 2003 was due to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
increased demand for the company's offerings associated with moderate expansion of the economy, as well as the company's continued market share gains
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Favorable
impact of currency translation partly offset by related hedging activity </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following is an analysis of the external segment results. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global
Services revenue increased 10.1&nbsp;percent (5.7&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency). SO revenue increased 12&nbsp;percent as each geography had
year-to-year revenue growth. ITS revenue increased 8&nbsp;percent helped by continued growth in Business Continuity and Recovery Services. BCS revenue increased
12&nbsp;percent year-to-year, with double-digit growth in both the America and Asia Pacific and high single-digit growth in EMEA. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company achieved Global Services signings of $12.7&nbsp;billion, including 13 signings over $100&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's Systems&nbsp;&amp; Technology Group revenue grew 4.9&nbsp;percent (1.3&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency). xSeries server revenue increased 25&nbsp;percent
year-to-year driven by solid performance in both high-end and 1&amp;2 Way servers. The IBM Blade servers continued their strong growth in the fourth quarter of 2004. pSeries
revenue increased 15&nbsp;percent year-to-year in the fourth quarter, reflecting very strong client acceptance of the POWER5 systems technology. OEM grew 10&nbsp;percent
year-to-year in the fourth quarter driven by improved yields in the 300 millimeter line where output grew 40&nbsp;percent versus the third quarter and Engineering &amp;
Technology Services business revenue grew at 61&nbsp;percent year-to-year. These increases were partially offset by lower zSeries server revenue of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=18,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=1026038,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CK2534A.;30',USER='MREYES',CD='23-FEB-2005;19:25' -->
<A NAME="page_ck2534_1_26"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>4&nbsp;percent
on MIPS growth of 6&nbsp;percent in the fourth quarter of 2004. iSeries server revenue declined 9&nbsp;percent year-to-year, however, strong customer
acceptance of the refreshed POWER5 iSeries drove sequential revenue growth. Storage Products revenue declined
11&nbsp;percent year-to-year. Total Disk products declined 15&nbsp;percent as the company transitions to new products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Personal
Systems Group revenue increased 1.8&nbsp;percent (declined 1.7&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency) driven by increased ThinkPad mobile computers. The company experienced
some disruption due to the Lenovo agreement, which was announced in the seasonally strongest month of the year. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Software
revenue increased 7.0&nbsp;percent (2.9&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency). The WebSphere family of software products grew 18&nbsp;percent for the quarter. Application
servers grew 33&nbsp;percent following the October announcement of a new release that provided improved security and integration of Web Services. Business Integration products grew
17&nbsp;percent. Rational revenue grew 8&nbsp;percent in the quarter, with growth across all product areas. Data Management software grew 8&nbsp;percent as DB2 database software grew
15&nbsp;percent, driven by double-digit growth in both host and distributed platforms and distributed enterprise content management software grew 31&nbsp;percent. Tivoli software increased
25&nbsp;percent, as Systems Management software grew 31&nbsp;percent, storage software increased 19&nbsp;percent and security software increased 9&nbsp;percent. Lotus software increased
5&nbsp;percent as Domino products grew 2&nbsp;percent for the quarter driven by the Notes messaging products. Other Foundation middleware products declined 2&nbsp;percent for the quarter. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global
Financing revenue declined 10.4&nbsp;percent (13.5&nbsp;percent adjusting for currency) driven primarily by a decline in used equipment sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's gross profit margin increased 0.8&nbsp;percentage points to 39.2&nbsp;percent. The Hardware gross profit margin improved 2&nbsp;percentage points with improving
margins in most product areas. Global Financing gross profit margin improved 7.5&nbsp;percentage points to 59.7&nbsp;percent primarily driven by improved used equipment sales and financing margins
and an improvement in mix toward higher margin financing revenue. Global Services and Software gross profit margin improved slightly year-over-year. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
expense and other income increased 6.4&nbsp;percent in the fourth quarter and revenue increased 6.8&nbsp;percent resulting in the total
expense-to-revenue ratio improvement of 0.1 point to 23.4&nbsp;percent. Retirement-related plan expenses increased $150&nbsp;million year-to-year
and were partially offset by lower workforce rebalancing expense of $75&nbsp;million. RD&amp;E expense increased 8.2&nbsp;percent or $112&nbsp;million, driven by increased spending in the Software
and Systems and Technology Group segments. In addition, the company recorded a provision for litigation-related expenses of $125&nbsp;million in SG&amp;A and the effects of currency was an addition to
expense of approximately $150&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's 2004 fourth quarter effective tax rate was 30.0&nbsp;percent, the same as 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share
repurchases totaled approximately $2.9&nbsp;billion in the fourth quarter. The weighted-average number of diluted common shares outstanding in the quarter was
1,691.6&nbsp;million compared with 1,745.7&nbsp;million in the 2003 fourth quarter, lower by 54.1&nbsp;million shares. The decreased amount of shares was driven primarily by the company's
ongoing common share repurchase program. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company generated slightly lower cash flows from operations in the 2004 fourth quarter as compared to the 2003 fourth quarter primarily due to higher pension funding driven by the
$700&nbsp;million funding of the PPP and approximately $500&nbsp;million funding of non-U.S. plans. The company also had an increase in acquisitions (primarily the Maersk Data/DMdata
acquisition in the fourth quarter of 2004) compared to the same period of 2003. Finally, the company repurchased $2,932&nbsp;million in shares during the 2004 fourth quarter compared with
$3,069&nbsp;million in shares repurchased during the 2003 fourth quarter. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=3><B>Prior Year in Review  </B></FONT></P>

at constant currency

<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>NM&#151;Not
Meaningful </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=19,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=84358,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CK2534A.;30',USER='MREYES',CD='23-FEB-2005;19:25' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_cm2534_1_27"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>CONTINUING OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in the company's 2003 Income from continuing operations and diluted earnings per share from continuing operations as compared to 2002 was due to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
results of the company's productivity and efficiency initiatives, including the benefits from the 2002 Microelectronics and productivity restructuring actions
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Stronger
demand associated with the improving economy (especially during the fourth quarter) and continued market share gains
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
charges recorded in 2002 for the 2002 actions (See note&nbsp;s, "2002 Actions" on pages&nbsp;73 through 76 for additional information.)
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Favorable
impact of currency translation, partly offset by related hedging activities </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in revenue in 2003 as compared to 2002 was due to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Stronger
demand associated with the improving economy (especially during the fourth quarter) and continued market share gains
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
impact of the fourth quarter 2002 acquisition of PricewaterhouseCoopers' consulting business (PwCC) and the first quarter 2003 acquisition of Rational, partially offset
by decreases in revenue due to Systems and Technology Group divestitures
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
favorable impact of currency translation, which contributed 7.0 points of the 9.8&nbsp;percent revenue increase. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue
for all industry sectors increased in 2003 on an as-reported basis, which has been reclassified to conform with the 2004 presentation. The Financial Services sector
(12.5 percent), Public sector (14.3&nbsp;percent), and Industrial sector (14.8&nbsp;percent) were among the strongest, with continued growth (12.5&nbsp;percent) in the Small&nbsp;&amp; Medium
Business sector. These results reflect the company's go-to-market strategy of designing industry-specific solutions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Full-year
geographic revenue increased across all geographies. In the Americas revenue increased 5&nbsp;percent. U.S. (3 percent) and Canada (13 percent) revenue grew as
did Latin America (6&nbsp;percent), notably in Brazil (26&nbsp;percent). In Europe/Middle East/Africa, revenue increased 20&nbsp;percent and was highest in the U.K. (17&nbsp;percent), Central
Europe and Middle East and Africa. In Asia Pacific revenue increased 13&nbsp;percent, while 2003 revenue for Japan, which is about 60&nbsp;percent of the region's revenue, increased
7&nbsp;percent compared with 2002. Australia/New Zealand (32&nbsp;percent) also achieved strong performance within Asia Pacific. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
OEM revenue, representing three percent of the company's revenue, declined, the decline was smaller than the prior year decline. The year-to-year percent
change in revenue (a decline of 21.4&nbsp;percent) reflects, in large part, the company's exit from its interconnect products business in 2002, as well as sluggish demand from certain OEM clients. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following is an analysis of external segment results. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Global Services  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global Services revenue increased 17.3&nbsp;percent (9.3&nbsp;percent at constant currency) in 2003 versus 2002. SO revenue increased 14.2&nbsp;percent in
2003 primarily driven by new signings. SO continued to demonstrate its competitive advantage in delivering on demand solutions by leveraging its business transformation skills and its scale during
2003. e-business Hosting Services, an offering that provides Web infrastructure and application management as an Internet-based service, continued its strong pattern of revenue growth. BCS
revenue increased 37.5&nbsp;percent in 2003 due to the acquisition of PwCC in the fourth quarter of 2002. ITS revenue increased 3.3&nbsp;percent due to the favorable impact of currency movements.
During 2003, the company changed its reporting for certain OEM hardware sales to the company's clients from gross to net revenue treatment based upon a review of the terms of these sales. The company
determined that the agent-like characteristics of these transactions were more appropriately recorded on a net revenue basis. Due to the amounts involved, the prior year amounts were not
adjusted. As a result of this change in 2003, revenue and costs for ITS were lower by $279&nbsp;million in 2003 as compared to 2002, partially offsetting the currency impact discussed above. This
change had no impact on the company's gross profit dollars, net income or cash
flows. The company signed $55&nbsp;billion of services contracts in 2003, an increase of $2&nbsp;billion versus 2002. The estimated services backlog at December&nbsp;31, 2003, was
$120&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Hardware Segments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Systems and Technology Group revenue increased 1.7&nbsp;percent (decreased 4.2&nbsp;percent at constant currency) in 2003 versus 2002. xSeries server products
revenue increased 16.8&nbsp;percent due to growth in sales of high-volume servers supported by strong growth in blades. The pSeries server revenues increased 12.5&nbsp;percent due to
strong demand for the 64-bit POWER systems across both the low-end and high-end server offerings. Revenue from the zSeries servers increased 7.4&nbsp;percent. The
total delivery of zSeries computing power as measured in MIPS increased more than 28&nbsp;percent in 2003 as compared to 2002. This increase was offset by lower average price per MIPS in 2003 of
19&nbsp;percent versus 2002. Revenue from the iSeries servers increased in all four quarters of 2003 when compared to 2002. Storage Systems revenue increased 9.8&nbsp;percent due to growth in
external disk and tape products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Microelectronics
revenue declined 31.6&nbsp;percent in 2003 versus 2002 driven by actions taken in 2002 to refocus and redirect its business to high-end foundry, ASICs and
standard products. These actions included the divestiture of multiple non-core businesses. There was also sluggish demand from certain OEM clients that contributed to this decline. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Personal
Systems Group revenue increased 3.1&nbsp;percent (down 2.5&nbsp;percent at constant currency) in 2003 versus 2002. Revenue from mobile personal computers increased
(10.9&nbsp;percent) due to strong demand and was offset by lower desktop personal computer revenue (4.0&nbsp;percent). The decreased desktop revenue primarily reflects the fact that increased
volume gains were not enough to offset a reduction in price due to decreasing commodity costs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=20,EFW="2152314",CP="IBM CORPORATION",DN="5",CHK=541153,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK021:[05NYC4.05NYC2534]CM2534A.;22',USER='MKEANE',CD='23-FEB-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_cm2534_1_28"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Software  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Software revenue increased 9.4&nbsp;percent (1.9&nbsp;percent at constant currency) in 2003 versus 2002, driven by Middleware software products. The WebSphere
family of software offerings revenue increased 11.8&nbsp;percent as clients continued to focus on the higher function products that integrate Web-based applications, including advanced
collaboration technology, on a user's desktop. The lower-function WebSphere application server continued to commoditize. Improved demand was also noted for Data Management DB2 database software.
Revenue from Tivoli products increased 12.0&nbsp;percent as clients continue to realize the on demand attributes of Tivoli products, enabling businesses to securely automate many of their processes
and gain operational efficiencies. Operating system software revenue increased 6.2&nbsp;percent due to the favorable impacts of currency movements. Offsetting these increases were lower demand for
DB2 tools, Lotus advanced collaboration software, and Other middleware software. A new Lotus messaging platform became generally available during the 2003 fourth quarter and helped to drive momentum
in the Lotus Notes family of products towards the end of 2003. Overall, the increase in total Software revenue was mainly due to the
acquisition of Rational in the first quarter of 2003. When compared to the separately reported 2002 external revenue amounts for Rational, its revenue increased approximately 6&nbsp;percent in 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Global Financing  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See pages&nbsp;35 to 39 for prior year review of Global Financing. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Enterprise Investments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue from Enterprise Investments increased 4.2&nbsp;percent (down 5.1&nbsp;percent at constant currency) in 2003 versus 2002. The decline was attributable
to demand for product life-cycle management software in the European market, especially in the automotive and aerospace industries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's gross profit margins remained relatively flat. Increases in margins for Hardware of 0.7 point resulting from the ongoing benefits from the company's integrated supply chain
initiatives and Software of 2.1 points resulting from favorable currency translation were offset by decreases in Global Services margins of 1.1 points driven primarily by investment costs on the early
stages of an SO contract and the company's changing mix of revenue toward BCS. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed above, there were several charges in 2002 that impacted the year-to-year expense comparison. These items contributed 2.8 points of the improvement in
the Total expense and other income-to-revenue ratio. The remaining improvement was primarily due to the results of productivity and efficiency initiatives offset by an increase
in retirement-related plans cost. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company's effective tax rate increased from 29.1&nbsp;percent in 2002 to 30.0&nbsp;percent in 2003. This increase was primarily due to a less favorable mix of geographic income
and the absence of the tax benefit associated with the Microelectronics actions taken in the second quarter of 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
regard to Assets, approximately $7&nbsp;billion of the increase relates to the impact of currency translation. The remaining increase primarily consists of an increase in Goodwill
of $2.8&nbsp;billion associated with recent acquisitions, increased pension assets of $2.4&nbsp;billion, as well as strong cash performance. The increase in cash during 2003 was due to the
combination of stronger operating results and lower pension funding. The company reduced non-Global Financing debt in 2003 as a result of strong cash flows from operations. Global
Financing debt also decreased, but the company's Global Financing debt-to-equity ratio remained flat at 6.9 to 1 and within the company's target range. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
ratio of unguaranteed residual value as a percentage of the related original amount financed declined 0.3 point to 3.6&nbsp;percent at December&nbsp;31, 2003, as compared to
December&nbsp;31, 2002, due to an increase in the percentage of leases that contain bargain purchase options. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;31, 2002, the company sold its HDD business to Hitachi for approximately $2&nbsp;billion. The majority of the cash was received with the
remaining payment due in December&nbsp;2005. The HDD business was accounted for as a discontinued operation whereby the results of operations and cash flows were removed from the company's results
from continuing operations for all periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company incurred a loss from discontinued operations of $1,755&nbsp;million in 2002, net of tax. The loss in 2002 was due to (amounts are net-of-tax): </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Loss
on operational results ($620&nbsp;million)
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Loss
on sale ($382&nbsp;million)
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Certain
actions taken by the company in the second and fourth quarters of 2002 ($508&nbsp;million) related to the HDD business
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Inventory
write-offs resulting from a strategic decision to cease reworking and selling efforts for some of the older HDD products after the announcement of the
divestiture plans ($245&nbsp;million) </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=3><B>Looking Forward  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following key drivers impacting the company's business are discussed on page&nbsp;17: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Economic
environment and corporate IT spending budgets
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Internal
business transformation and efficiency initiatives
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Innovations
initiatives
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Open
standards
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Emerging
business opportunities </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
respect to the economic environment, while it is always difficult to predict future economic trends, in 2004 the economic environment improved&#151;shifting from a period of
recovery to moderate expansion. Going forward, we anticipate moderate growth for the traditional IT industry. Several factors&#151;including increasing complexity and
globalization&#151;are driving clients to transform their businesses. The year-to-year and sequential quarterly growth trend comparisons achieved by the company are
indicators of this improvement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
respect to business transformation and the continual conversion of the company into an on demand business, the company's supply chain initiatives are expected to allow continued
flexibility to drive additional competitive advantages. The company will continue to focus on increased productivity and efficiency to accelerate the globalization and transformation of its global
business model. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Finally,
with respect to technology, in 2004 the company has again been awarded more U.S. patents than any other company for the twelfth year in a row. The company continues to focus
internal development investments on high-growth opportunities and to broaden its ability to deliver industry- and client-specific solutions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;From
a client-set perspective, the strong momentum in 2004 with respect to the Small &amp; Medium Business sector should continue. We anticipate continued growth in the
Communications, Distribution and Public sectors, however, the Financial Services sector growth may moderate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
company also will selectively pursue acquisitions, primarily in the Global Services and Software segments, where it believes these acquisitions will expand its portfolio to meet
clients' needs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Global Services Signings  </B></FONT></P>
